selected_quotes: for anyone watching #TheXFiles looking for the paper
Large-scale recent expansion of European patrilineages shown by population resequencing r1ar1b blew up in bronze age
Scully: There was a study published last year
Ha! Excellent use of actual research

citation.abstract: The proportion of Europeans descending from Neolithic farmers ∼10 thousand years ago (KYA) or Palaeolithic hunter-gatherers has been much debated. The male-specific region of the Y chromosome (MSY) has been widely applied to this question, but unbiased estimates of diversity and time depth have been lacking. Here we show that European patrilineages underwent a recent continent-wide expansion. Resequencing of 3.7 Mb of MSY DNA in 334 males, comprising 17 European and Middle Eastern populations, defines a phylogeny containing 5,996 single-nucleotide polymorphisms. Dating indicates that three major lineages (I1, R1a and R1b), accounting for 64% of our sample, have very recent coalescent times, ranging between 3.5 and 7.3 KYA. A continuous swathe of 13/17 populations share similar histories featuring a demographic expansion starting ∼2.1-4.2 KYA. Our results are compatible with ancient MSY DNA data, and contrast with data on mitochondrial DNA, indicating a widespread male-specific phenomenon that focuses interest on the social structure of Bronze Age Europe.
citation.title: Large-scale recent expansion of European patrilineages shown by population resequencing

wikipedia.title: Human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup
wikipedia.summary: In human genetics, a human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup is a haplogroup defined by differences in the non-recombining portions of DNA from the Y chromosome (called Y-DNA).

facebook.title: A handful of Bronze-Age men could have fathered two thirds of Europeans
facebook.summary: 64% of modern European men belong to the paternal lineage of just three individuals living between 3,500 and 7,300 years ago – according to research published in Nature Communications. Read the paper here: http://bit.ly/1HGt4iK

facebook.title: Large-scale recent expansion of European patrilineages shown by population resequencing : Nature...
facebook.summary:
WOAH!
Recent paper suggests that two-thirds of European Y chromosomes existing today can be traced back to 3 individuals alive between 3500 and 7300 years ago.
(though sample size=334 samples, is modest)
